thread.title: Wolverines' Jourdan Lewis graded as best CB in college football
thread.title_full: Wolverines' Jourdan Lewis graded as best CB in college football

author: freep.com
title: Wolverines' Jourdan Lewis graded as best CB in college football
text:
MORE Pro Football Focus has Michigan cornerback Jourdan Lewis rated as the No. 1 player at his position in college football, with a grade of plus-11.1 this season.
PFF grades take into account each player on each play.
Lewis this season has seven pass break-ups and one interception, plus 13 tackles, including one for loss.
According to PFF's college staff, "opposing QBs have a completion % of 23.1% and NFL passer rating of 36.4" when targeting Lewis.
"He just knows football. His IQ of football is really high," said U-M receiver Maurice Ways, who battles Lewis in practice. "He knows splits, alignments, he knows personnel, in terms of who he's going against, what their strengths are, what their weaknesses are. Athletic quick, heck of an athlete. A great corner."
Lewis, a junior from Detroit Cass Tech, won a starting job in the middle of last season and was the Wolverines' only certainty at the position entering this year. Junior Channing Stribling has become more consistent, and Jeremy Clark shifted from safety, giving U-M a potent rotation between the three of them this season.
Highlighting Lewis was only part of PFF's look at the Michigan-Northwestern defensive battle Saturday at Michigan Stadium (3:30 p.m., BTN).
The website notes that U-M's defense ranks No. 3 nationally without a preseason All-Big Ten selection, and Michigan is the "the only team with a top-three run defense and pass rush, according to our grades."
In other rankings, they have Chris Wormley and Maurice Hurst as the most impactful defensive linemen in college football.
Jabrill Peppers ranks 11th nationally among safeties.
